newsitem.title: FRANCE: TENNIS-KUERTEN HOISTS BRAZIL FLAG A YEAR EARLY IN PARIS.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-KUERTEN HOISTS BRAZIL FLAG A YEAR EARLY IN PARIS.

text.p: Brazil were expected to shine in Paris next year at the soccer World Cup finals but nobody thought they would impress at the French Open until Gustavo Kuerten came along.
Kuerten, who became the first Brazilian man to reach a Grand Slam final by beating Belgian Filip Dewulf in four sets on Friday, has won the hearts of Parisians with his Prince Charming qualities.
The 20-year-old from Florianopolis, regarded merely as an exotic attraction before the event started, has delighted the crowds with his fresh, relaxed attitude and a spectacular attacking game.
His on court demeanour is impeccable. He rarely contests a line call, jokes with the ball boys and after a match is equally happy to mix with the fans as the media.

"I try to be the same guy off and on the court and maybe that's what brings me luck," he said after his 6-1 3-6 6-1 7-6 victory on Friday. "Even if I win the final, I'll still be just like any other guy you could meet on the street."
Even before his semifinal victory, Kuerten, who wears a flashy, yellow and blue outfit, had earned many headlines in the sports pages of the Brazilian newspapers, usually more interested in soccer.
"Football is the number one sport by far but now, they're discovering tennis," said Kuerten, who will meet either Sergi Bruguera of Spain or Australian Pat Rafter in Sunday's final.
He added he had received a fax of encouragement from Paris St Germain's Brazilian World Cup player Rai.
"He told me he would come and see me in the final," said Kuerten. "I'm ever so pleased."
The lean Brazilian, ranked a modest 66 in the world, won his first tournament, a satellite contest in Curitiba, Brazil, just before coming to Paris.

On the clay courts of Roland Garros, he has looked more like a seasoned professional, knocking over Austrian Thomas Muster, Andrei Medvedev of Ukraine and holder Yevgeny Kafelnikov of Russia on his way to the final.
"Every kid who loves tennis dreams of playing the final of a Grand Slam tournament," he said. "I'm no exception. It really is a dream come true. I'm so happy I just can't find the words."
Asked if he thought he could win the tournament, Kuerten replied, "Why not?".
"I'm looking forward to going out there on Sunday with the big crowd and everything. And if I stay calm and just go for my shots, you never know, I could win."
